awd_titl_txt: Directed Synthesis of a Pure Spin Liquid - Towards a Comprehensive Theory of High-Tc Superconductivity
awd_abstract_narration:
The Division of Chemistry supports Danna Freedman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as an American Competitiveness in Chemistry Fellow.  Dr. Freedman will work with Prof. Dan Nocera to create compositionally-pure crystals of materials which can be used to make high-temperature superconductors, according to Anderson's resonating valence bond (RVB) theory.  The synthesis of these crystals will be guided by results from a new kind of anomalous x-ray scattering measurements made at the ChemMatCARS beamline of the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory.  Dr. Freedman will be collaborating with Dr. Yu-Sheng Chen, a Research Beamline Scientist at ChemMat CARS.  For her plan for broadening participation, the PI will work with the Center for Materials Science and Engineering to develop curriculum on chemistry and how this relates to energy issues, including superconductivity, to be used with local middle school students, including a significant fraction from underrepresented groups.

Research like that of Dr. Freedman is aimed ultimately at developing more efficient electrical conductors -- a technology area that can yield greater efficiencies in e.g. electrical power distribution.  The efforts at broadening participation being pursued by Dr. Freedman are aimed at encouraging young people from all walks of life to develop a better understanding of science and to possibly pursue careers in science.

por.por_cntn:
Superconductors have the potential for a transformative impact on our energy landscape. Twenty-five years ago superconductors which operate at temperatures greater than that of liquid nitrogen were discovered. These superconductors have the capability to conduct electricity without energy loss and to increase the current density of our power grid without requiring expensive and rare liquid helium as a coolant. Based on this development, superconductors of this type were recently installed in Long Island. While these superconductors are incredible, we cannot improve upon them without understand their mechanism of action.

The overarching goal of this research project was to create a model compound based on one of the many competing theories and pursue its physical properties and to determine if there is overlap between the observed properties of the model compound and the known superconductors to validate or invalidate this theory and inform the synthesis of new superconductors. To achieve this, prior to the start of this project, a compound known as herbertsmithite was synthesized. This compound was thought to match one of the primary criteria, the potential for a state in which all of the electrons behave collectively. Herbertsmithite is a geometrically perfect kagomé lattice, thought to engender geometric magnetic frustration thus creating the potential to create a fully delocalized state across the entire system, similar to the state of a superconductor. However, the structure of herbertsmithite was not fully understood prior to the start of this research. It was posited that structural defects led to the unusual observed magnetic properties. Our research project sought to better understand this system, determine if it is truly a perfect lattice and based on that data determine its physical properties.

Towards those ends, during the project time frame we developed a new X-ray scattering technique in collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory that allows us to determine the identity of chemical elements on specific areas of the crystal. Using this methodology we were able to establish the physical properties of herbertsmithite and determine that the lattice truly is perfect and thus the explanation for its exotic behavior must therefore be a delocalized state as predicted. This exciting result enabled inelastic neutron scattering studies, which are in progress. Those studies will be able to provide additional information about the properties of this system. During this time we also pursued the synthesis of new geometrically frustrated lattices to extend the research to systems with larger number of electrons to test the quantum properties of the system.

This research was also used as a part of an outreach organized through the MIT Materials Science Research and Engineering Center. During that outreach activity, local middle school students came to MIT and were introduced to the concept of superconductivity and transition temperatures through lectures and demonstrations. Students also performed a chemical synthesis of the oldest known coordination complex, Prussian Blue.
